page.title: 01LANDSCAPE AND BUILDINGS
page.content: Edington and Coulston are just two of many small villages tucked under the northern escarpment of the Salisbury Plain.They grew on the spring line,making ideal trading places for the hill farmers from the plain and the lowland farmers to the north.The fresh spring water was used for washing fleeces and for turning mills for grinding corn. Today the lowland farms remain, with names like Hudd's Mill and Ivy Mill, but the majority of farms from the plain have vanished with the take over by the army for manoevres.Edington itself has a fine 14c.Priory Church,visited by thousands every year,built as the home for the Bonhommes monastic order. The landscape is dominated by the plain escarpment,resembling a steep,ploughed,field,eroded by many small,dry valleys.
